title: July 2011 Licensure Paper Three
description: NCK July 2011 Paper Three Licensure Examination covering Community Health Nursing, Mental Health & Midwifery (Parts I, II & III).

questions.question: Activities categorized as secondary disease prevention include:

options.text: Blood pressure screening, guarding against accidents, actual treatment of disease
Chemoprophylaxis, annual pap smear test, supply of safe drinking water
Routine mammography, blood pressure screening, annual pap smear test
Periodic determination of blood cholesterol, supply of safe drinking water

questions.explanation: Secondary prevention focuses on early diagnosis and prompt treatment (screening). Safe drinking water is primary prevention.
questions.hint: Focus on screening and early detection methods.

questions.question: The occupational disease that would occur in workers employed in a sugar cane factory is:
questions.explanation: Bagassosis is caused by inhaling dust from bagasse (sugar cane residue). Byssinosis is cotton dust; Siderosis is iron dust.
questions.hint: Think about the residue of sugar cane called 'bagasse'.

questions.question: An abiotic environment that can affect health of the community is:
questions.explanation: Abiotic factors are non-living chemical and physical parts of the environment. Organisms, insects, and vegetation are biotic (living).
questions.hint: 'Abiotic' means non-living.

questions.question: The measurement rate that is used to determine the number of new cases of a disease over an interval of time is:
questions.explanation: Incidence measures NEW cases. Prevalence measures existing (new + old) cases.
questions.hint: Think 'Incidents' happen anew.

questions.question: The term used to describe malaria endemicity patterns where transmission occurs all the year round is:
questions.explanation: Holoendemic areas have intense, perennial (year-round) transmission.
questions.hint: This term represents the highest intensity of transmission.

questions.question: The fungal skin infection characterized by thickening and discoloration of the nails is called:
questions.explanation: Tinea unguium (Onychomycosis) affects the nails. Tinea pedis is athlete's foot.
questions.hint: 'Unguium' refers to the nail (unguis).

questions.question: The infection of the genital tract where the discharge has a fishy or ammonia odour is:
questions.explanation: Trichomoniasis (and Bacterial Vaginosis) is associated with a foul, fishy odor. Candidiasis is odorless.
questions.hint: Candidiasis is usually white/curdy, Gonorrhea is purulent. This one smells bad.

questions.question: A zoonotic disease that is caused by a spore forming bacillus is:
questions.explanation: Anthrax is caused by Bacillus anthracis, which is spore-forming.
questions.hint: This bacteria can survive in the soil for decades as spores.

questions.question: A research instrument that is able to give same measurements when recreated several times is said to be:
questions.explanation: Reliability refers to consistency/repeatability. Validity refers to accuracy (measuring what it is supposed to measure).
questions.hint: If a car starts every morning, it is...

questions.question: The statistical measurement that takes into account all scores obtained and responded to the exact position of every score relative to the mean of that distribution is the:
questions.explanation: Standard deviation measures dispersion using every score's distance from the mean.
questions.hint: It measures how 'deviated' scores are from the standard (mean).

questions.question: The hypothesis that rivals the null hypothesis is referred to as:
questions.explanation: The Alternative Hypothesis (H1) contradicts the Null Hypothesis (H0).
questions.hint: It is the 'alternative' to the null.

questions.question: Family descent where the membership is acquired through the male line is:
questions.explanation: Patrilineal traces descent through the father (male line). Patrilocal refers to residence.
questions.hint: 'Pater' means father.

questions.question: The home visiting phase where the nurse designs a plan of action for the family is:
questions.explanation: Planning happens before the visit (Pre-visit phase) based on available records.
questions.hint: You plan before you go.

questions.question: Biphasic pills include:
questions.explanation: Ovanon is a sequential pill often classified with biphasic types. Logynon is Triphasic. Microgynon is Monophasic.
questions.hint: Logynon has 3 phases (Tri). Microgynon has 1 phase (Mono).

questions.question: Following vasectomy procedure, the client should be advised to use condoms or another family planning method for a duration of:
questions.explanation: It takes about 3 months (or ~20 ejaculations) to clear remaining sperm from the ducts.
questions.hint: It takes about 12 weeks.

questions.question: The age at which a child is likely to conceptualize abstract ideas is:
questions.explanation: Formal Operational Stage (Abstract thinking) begins around age 12 (Piaget).
questions.hint: This coincides with the start of adolescence.

questions.question: Water-washed diseases include:
questions.explanation: Water-washed diseases (e.g., Scabies, Trachoma) are due to lack of water for hygiene. Typhoid/Cholera are water-borne.
questions.hint: Diseases prevented by washing the face and body.

questions.question: In health education, the principle that best addressed the felt needs of the people is:
questions.explanation: People are interested in what they feel they need. Interest addresses 'felt needs'.
questions.hint: People learn best when they are ______ in the topic.

questions.question: Some of the health issues classified under the high priority health package in Kenya are:

options.text: Mental health, control of vector-borne diseases

questions.explanation: KEPH priorities include Reproductive Health and major communicable diseases like Malaria.
questions.hint: Think about the biggest killers in the region (Maternal mortality, Malaria).

questions.question: Increasing the ability of the population to cope with a disaster is known as:
questions.explanation: Preparedness builds capacity to cope/respond. Mitigation reduces severity.
questions.hint: Being ready.

questions.question: Arrange the stages of the normal reaction to the BCG vaccine in chronological order:
questions.explanation: 1. Immediate wheal 2. Papule forms 3. Papule ulcerates 4. Heals with scar.
questions.hint: It starts with the injection wheal and ends with a scar.

questions.question: Match the anthropometric measurement to the growth condition it primarily monitors:
questions.explanation: Weight/Age monitors general growth. Height/Age detects chronic issues (stunting). MUAC/Weight-for-Height detects acute wasting.
questions.hint: Height takes time to change (Chronic). Muscles waste quickly (Acute).

questions.question: Which of the following factors should be considered when planning group health education? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Key factors: Audience, Topic, Objectives, Venue, Methods, Language (simple), Time, Evaluation.
questions.hint: Avoid jargon.

questions.question: Which of the following are goals of Focused Antenatal Care (FANC)? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Early detection and treatment of complications

questions.explanation: FANC goals: Disease detection/treatment, Prevention (IPT/TT), Birth preparedness, Health promotion.
questions.hint: Focus on the mother and baby's health.

questions.question: Which of the following are sources of demographic information? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Sources include Census, Vital Registration, Surveys, Migration records, and Facility records.
questions.hint: Look for official data sources.

questions.question: Match the vaccine to its correct administration schedule for a fully immunized child:
questions.explanation: BCG at birth, Penta 1 at 6 weeks, Measles at 9 months.
questions.hint: Measles is usually the last one in the infant schedule.

questions.question: Regarding Multi-Drug Resistant Tuberculosis (MDR-TB), which statements are correct? (Select all that apply)

options.text: It is resistant to Isoniazid and Rifampicin.
Poor adherence to treatment is a major risk factor.
Management requires isolation and second-line drugs.

questions.explanation: MDR-TB is resistant to the two most powerful first-line drugs. It requires isolation and second-line treatment (DOTS-Plus).
questions.hint: MDR means resistance to the best drugs.
